trans-unit.source: .NET multi-tier application | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: .NET multi-tier application | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that helps you develop a multi-tier app in Azure that uses Service Bus queues to communicate between tiers. Samples in .NET.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that helps you develop a multi-tier app in Azure that uses Service Bus queues to communicate between tiers. Samples in .NET.

trans-unit.source: Developing for Microsoft Azure is easy using Visual Studio 2013 and the free Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: Developing for Microsoft Azure is easy using Visual Studio 2013 and the free Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK will automatically install Visual Studio Express, so you can start developing for Azure entirely for free.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK will automatically install Visual Studio Express, so you can start developing for Azure entirely for free.

trans-unit.source: This article assumes you have no prior experience using Azure.
trans-unit.target: This article assumes you have no prior experience using Azure.

trans-unit.source: After completing this tutorial, you will have an application that uses multiple Azure resources running in your local environment and that demonstrates how a multi-tier application works.
trans-unit.target: After completing this tutorial, you will have an application that uses multiple Azure resources running in your local environment and that demonstrates how a multi-tier application works.

trans-unit.source: You will learn:
trans-unit.target: You will learn:

trans-unit.source: How to enable your computer for Azure development with a single download and install.
trans-unit.target: How to enable your computer for Azure development with a single download and install.

trans-unit.source: How to use Visual Studio to develop for Azure.
trans-unit.target: How to use Visual Studio to develop for Azure.

trans-unit.source: How to create a multi-tier application in Azure using web and worker roles.
trans-unit.target: How to create a multi-tier application in Azure using web and worker roles.

trans-unit.source: How to communicate between tiers using Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: How to communicate between tiers using Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you'll build and run the multi-tier application in an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you'll build and run the multi-tier application in an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The front end will be an ASP.NET MVC web role and the back end will be a worker-role.
trans-unit.target: The front end will be an ASP.NET MVC web role and the back end will be a worker-role.

trans-unit.source: You can create the same multi-tier application with the front end as a web project that is deployed to an Azure website instead of a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You can create the same multi-tier application with the front end as a web project that is deployed to an Azure website instead of a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: For instructions about what to do differently on an Azure website front end, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For instructions about what to do differently on an Azure website front end, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: The following screen shot shows the completed application.
trans-unit.target: The following screen shot shows the completed application.

trans-unit.source: Azure also provides storage queue functionality.
trans-unit.target: Azure also provides storage queue functionality.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure storage queues and Service Bus queues, see <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues - Compared and Contrasted[sbqueuecomparison]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure storage queues and Service Bus queues, see <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues - Compared and Contrasted[sbqueuecomparison]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To submit an order for processing, the front end UI component, running in the web role, needs to interact with the middle tier logic running in the worker role.
trans-unit.target: To submit an order for processing, the front end UI component, running in the web role, needs to interact with the middle tier logic running in the worker role.

trans-unit.source: This example uses Service Bus brokered messaging for the communication between the tiers.
trans-unit.target: This example uses Service Bus brokered messaging for the communication between the tiers.

trans-unit.source: Using brokered messaging between the web and middle tiers decouples the two components.
trans-unit.target: Using brokered messaging between the web and middle tiers decouples the two components.

trans-unit.source: In contrast to direct messaging (that is, TCP or HTTP), the web tier does not connect to the middle tier directly; instead it pushes units of work, as messages, into the Service Bus, which reliably retains them until the middle tier is ready to consume and process them.
trans-unit.target: In contrast to direct messaging (that is, TCP or HTTP), the web tier does not connect to the middle tier directly; instead it pushes units of work, as messages, into the Service Bus, which reliably retains them until the middle tier is ready to consume and process them.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides two entities to support brokered messaging: queues and topics.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides two entities to support brokered messaging: queues and topics.

trans-unit.source: With queues, each message sent to the queue is consumed by a single receiver.
trans-unit.target: With queues, each message sent to the queue is consumed by a single receiver.

trans-unit.source: Topics support the publish/subscribe pattern in which each published message is made available to a subscription registered with the topic.
trans-unit.target: Topics support the publish/subscribe pattern in which each published message is made available to a subscription registered with the topic.

trans-unit.source: Each subscription logically maintains its own queue of messages.
trans-unit.target: Each subscription logically maintains its own queue of messages.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions can also be configured with filter rules that restrict the set of messages passed to the subscription queue to those that match the filter.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions can also be configured with filter rules that restrict the set of messages passed to the subscription queue to those that match the filter.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: This communication mechanism has several advantages over direct messaging:
trans-unit.target: This communication mechanism has several advantages over direct messaging:

trans-unit.source: Temporal decoupling. With the asynchronous messaging pattern, producers and consumers need not be online at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Temporal decoupling. With the asynchronous messaging pattern, producers and consumers need not be online at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus reliably stores messages until the consuming party is ready to receive them.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus reliably stores messages until the consuming party is ready to receive them.

trans-unit.source: This allows the components of the distributed application to be disconnected, either voluntarily, for example, for maintenance, or due to a component crash, without impacting the system as a whole.
trans-unit.target: This allows the components of the distributed application to be disconnected, either voluntarily, for example, for maintenance, or due to a component crash, without impacting the system as a whole.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, the consuming application may only need to come online during certain times of the day.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, the consuming application may only need to come online during certain times of the day.

trans-unit.source: Load leveling. In many applications, system load varies over time, while the processing time required for each unit of work is typically constant.
trans-unit.target: Load leveling. In many applications, system load varies over time, while the processing time required for each unit of work is typically constant.

trans-unit.source: Intermediating message producers and consumers with a queue means that the consuming application (the worker) only needs to be provisioned to accommodate average load rather than peak load.
trans-unit.target: Intermediating message producers and consumers with a queue means that the consuming application (the worker) only needs to be provisioned to accommodate average load rather than peak load.

trans-unit.source: The depth of the queue will grow and contract as the incoming load varies.
trans-unit.target: The depth of the queue will grow and contract as the incoming load varies.

trans-unit.source: This directly saves money in terms of the amount of infrastructure required to service the application load.
trans-unit.target: This directly saves money in terms of the amount of infrastructure required to service the application load.

trans-unit.source: Load balancing. As load increases, more worker processes can be added to read from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Load balancing. As load increases, more worker processes can be added to read from the queue.

trans-unit.source: Each message is processed by only one of the worker processes.
trans-unit.target: Each message is processed by only one of the worker processes.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, this pull-based load balancing allows for optimum utilization of the worker machines even if the worker machines differ in terms of processing power as they will pull messages at their own maximum rate.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, this pull-based load balancing allows for optimum utilization of the worker machines even if the worker machines differ in terms of processing power as they will pull messages at their own maximum rate.

trans-unit.source: This pattern is often termed the competing consumer pattern.
trans-unit.target: This pattern is often termed the competing consumer pattern.

trans-unit.source: The following sections discuss the code that implements this architecture.
trans-unit.target: The following sections discuss the code that implements this architecture.

trans-unit.source: Before you can begin developing your Azure application, download the tools and set up your development environment:
trans-unit.target: Before you can begin developing your Azure application, download the tools and set up your development environment:

trans-unit.source: To install the Azure SDK for .NET, click the following link.
trans-unit.target: To install the Azure SDK for .NET, click the following link.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get Tools and SDK</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get Tools and SDK</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Click the link for the version of Visual Studio you are using.
trans-unit.target: Click the link for the version of Visual Studio you are using.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this tutorial use Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this tutorial use Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: When prompted to run or save the installation file, click Run.
trans-unit.target: When prompted to run or save the installation file, click Run.

trans-unit.source: In the Web Platform Installer, click Install and proceed with the installation.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Platform Installer, click Install and proceed with the installation.

trans-unit.source: Once the installation is complete, you have everything necessary to start developing the app.
trans-unit.target: Once the installation is complete, you have everything necessary to start developing the app.

trans-unit.source: The SDK includes tools that enable you to develop Azure applications in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The SDK includes tools that enable you to develop Azure applications in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have Visual Studio installed, it also installs the free Visual Studio Express for Web.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have Visual Studio installed, it also installs the free Visual Studio Express for Web.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to create a service namespace, and to obtain a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to create a service namespace, and to obtain a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key.

trans-unit.source: A service namespace provides an application boundary for each application exposed through Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: A service namespace provides an application boundary for each application exposed through Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: A SAS key is generated by the system when a service namespace is created.
trans-unit.target: A SAS key is generated by the system when a service namespace is created.

trans-unit.source: The combination of service namespace and SAS key provides the credentials for Service Bus to authenticate access to an application.
trans-unit.target: The combination of service namespace and SAS key provides the credentials for Service Bus to authenticate access to an application.

trans-unit.source: You can also manage namespaces and Service Bus messaging entities using the Visual Studio Server Explorer, but you can only create new namespaces from within the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: You can also manage namespaces and Service Bus messaging entities using the Visual Studio Server Explorer, but you can only create new namespaces from within the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Log into the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log into the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Add a new namespace page, enter a namespace name.
trans-unit.target: In the Add a new namespace page, enter a namespace name.

trans-unit.source: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your compute resources).
trans-unit.target: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your compute resources).

trans-unit.source: Also, make sure that you select Messaging in the namespace Type field, and Standard in the Messaging Tier field.
trans-unit.target: Also, make sure that you select Messaging in the namespace Type field, and Standard in the Messaging Tier field.

trans-unit.source: Pick the same region that you intend to choose to deploy your application.
trans-unit.target: Pick the same region that you intend to choose to deploy your application.

trans-unit.source: This will give you the best performance.
trans-unit.target: This will give you the best performance.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: The system now creates your service namespace and enables it.
trans-unit.target: The system now creates your service namespace and enables it.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.

trans-unit.source: In the main window, click the name of your service namespace.
trans-unit.target: In the main window, click the name of your service namespace.

trans-unit.source: Click Connection Information.
trans-unit.target: Click Connection Information.

trans-unit.source: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.
trans-unit.target: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of these credentials, or copy them to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of these credentials, or copy them to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will build the front end of your application.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will build the front end of your application.

trans-unit.source: You will first create the various pages that your application displays.
trans-unit.target: You will first create the various pages that your application displays.

trans-unit.source: After that, you will add the code for submitting items to a Service Bus queue and displaying status information about the queue.
trans-unit.target: After that, you will add the code for submitting items to a Service Bus queue and displaying status information about the queue.

trans-unit.source: Using administrator privileges, start either Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 or Microsoft Visual Studio Express.
trans-unit.target: Using administrator privileges, start either Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 or Microsoft Visual Studio Express.

trans-unit.source: To start Visual Studio with administrator privileges, right-click Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 (or Microsoft Visual Studio Express) and then click Run as administrator.
trans-unit.target: To start Visual Studio with administrator privileges, right-click Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 (or Microsoft Visual Studio Express) and then click Run as administrator.

trans-unit.source: The Azure compute emulator, discussed later in this article, requires that Visual Studio be started with administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: The Azure compute emulator, discussed later in this article, requires that Visual Studio be started with administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, click New, and then click Project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the File menu, click New, and then click Project.

trans-unit.source: From Installed Templates, under Visual C#, click Cloud and then click Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: From Installed Templates, under Visual C#, click Cloud and then click Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: Name the project MultiTierApp.
trans-unit.target: Name the project MultiTierApp.

trans-unit.source: Then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Then click OK.

trans-unit.source: From .NET Framework 4.5 roles, double-click ASP.NET Web Role.
trans-unit.target: From .NET Framework 4.5 roles, double-click ASP.NET Web Role.

trans-unit.source: Hover over WebRole1 under Azure Cloud Service solution, click the pencil icon, and rename the web role to FrontendWebRole.
trans-unit.target: Hover over WebRole1 under Azure Cloud Service solution, click the pencil icon, and rename the web role to FrontendWebRole.

trans-unit.source: Then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Then click OK.

trans-unit.source: (Make sure you enter "Frontend" with a lower-case 'e,' not "FrontEnd".)
trans-unit.target: (Make sure you enter "Frontend" with a lower-case 'e,' not "FrontEnd".)

trans-unit.source: From the New ASP.NET Project dialog box, in the Select a template list, click MVC, then click OK.
trans-unit.target: From the New ASP.NET Project dialog box, in the Select a template list, click MVC, then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Manage NuGet Packages or Add Library Package Reference.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Manage NuGet Packages or Add Library Package Reference.

trans-unit.source: Select Online on the left side of the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Select Online on the left side of the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Search for "Service Bus" and select the Microsoft Azure Service Bus item.
trans-unit.target: Search for "Service Bus" and select the Microsoft Azure Service Bus item.

trans-unit.source: Then complete the installation and close this dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Then complete the installation and close this dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Note that the required client assemblies are now referenced and some new code files have been added.
trans-unit.target: Note that the required client assemblies are now referenced and some new code files have been added.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click Models and click Add, then click Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click Models and click Add, then click Class.

trans-unit.source: In the Name box, type the name OnlineOrder.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the Name box, type the name OnlineOrder.cs.

trans-unit.source: Then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Then click Add.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create the various pages that your application displays.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create the various pages that your application displays.

trans-unit.target: In the OnlineOrder.cs file in Visual Studio, replace the existing namespace definition with the following code:

trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click Controllers\HomeController.cs.

trans-unit.target: Add the following using statements at the top of the file to include the namespaces for the model you just created, as well as Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: Also in the HomeController.cs file in Visual Studio, replace the existing namespace definition with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Also in the HomeController.cs file in Visual Studio, replace the existing namespace definition with the following code.

trans-unit.source: This code contains methods for handling the submission of items to the queue.
trans-unit.target: This code contains methods for handling the submission of items to the queue.

trans-unit.source: On the Build menu, click Build Solution to test the accuracy of your work so far.
trans-unit.target: On the Build menu, click Build Solution to test the accuracy of your work so far.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will create the view for the Submit() method you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will create the view for the Submit() method you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Right-click within the Submit() method, and then choose Add View.
trans-unit.target: Right-click within the Submit() method, and then choose Add View.

trans-unit.source: A dialog box appears for creating the view.
trans-unit.target: A dialog box appears for creating the view.

trans-unit.source: In the Template list, choose Create.
trans-unit.target: In the Template list, choose Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Model class list, click the OnlineOrder class.
trans-unit.target: In the Model class list, click the OnlineOrder class.

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: Now, change the displayed name of your application.
trans-unit.target: Now, change the displayed name of your application.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click the Views\Shared\\_Layout.cshtml file to open it in the Visual Studio editor.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click the Views\Shared\\_Layout.cshtml file to open it in the Visual Studio editor.

trans-unit.source: Replace all occurrences of My ASP.NET Application with LITWARE'S Products.
trans-unit.target: Replace all occurrences of My ASP.NET Application with LITWARE'S Products.

trans-unit.source: Remove the Home, About, and Contact links.
trans-unit.target: Remove the Home, About, and Contact links.

trans-unit.source: Delete the highlighted code:
trans-unit.target: Delete the highlighted code:

trans-unit.source: Finally, modify the submission page to include some information about the queue.
trans-unit.target: Finally, modify the submission page to include some information about the queue.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click the Views\Home\Submit.cshtml file to open it in the Visual Studio editor.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click the Views\Home\Submit.cshtml file to open it in the Visual Studio editor.

trans-unit.target: For now, the ViewBag.MessageCount is empty.

trans-unit.source: You will populate it later.
trans-unit.target: You will populate it later.

trans-unit.source: You now have implemented your UI.
trans-unit.target: You now have implemented your UI.

trans-unit.source: You can press F5 to run your application and confirm that it looks as expected.
trans-unit.target: You can press F5 to run your application and confirm that it looks as expected.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will add code for submitting items to a queue.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will add code for submitting items to a queue.

trans-unit.source: You will first create a class that contains your Service Bus queue connection information.
trans-unit.target: You will first create a class that contains your Service Bus queue connection information.

trans-unit.target: Then, you will initialize your connection from Global.aspx.cs.

trans-unit.target: Finally, you will update the submission code you created earlier in HomeController.cs to actually submit items to a Service Bus queue.

trans-unit.target: Name the class QueueConnector.cs.

trans-unit.target: Now, ensure that your Initialize method gets called.

trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click Global.asax\Global.asax.cs.

trans-unit.source: Add the following line to the bottom of the Application_Start method.
trans-unit.target: Add the following line to the bottom of the Application_Start method.

trans-unit.source: Finally, update the web code you created earlier, to submit items to the queue.
trans-unit.target: Finally, update the web code you created earlier, to submit items to the queue.

trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click Controllers\HomeController.cs.

trans-unit.source: Update the Submit() method as follows to get the message count for the queue.
trans-unit.target: Update the Submit() method as follows to get the message count for the queue.

trans-unit.target: Update the Submit(OnlineOrder order) method as follows to submit order information to the queue.

trans-unit.source: Each time you submit an order, the message count increases.
trans-unit.target: Each time you submit an order, the message count increases.

trans-unit.source: The GetSettings method in the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.CloudConfigurationManager class enables you to read configuration settings from the configuration store for your platform.
trans-unit.target: The GetSettings method in the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.CloudConfigurationManager class enables you to read configuration settings from the configuration store for your platform.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your code is running in a web or worker role the GetSettings method reads the ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file, and if your code is running in a standard console app the GetSettings method reads the app.config file.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your code is running in a web or worker role the GetSettings method reads the ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file, and if your code is running in a standard console app the GetSettings method reads the app.config file.

trans-unit.source: If you store a connection string for your Service Bus namespace in a configuration file, you can use the GetSettings method to read a connection string that you can use to instantiate a NamespaceMananger object.
trans-unit.target: If you store a connection string for your Service Bus namespace in a configuration file, you can use the GetSettings method to read a connection string that you can use to instantiate a NamespaceMananger object.

trans-unit.source: You can use a NamespaceMananger instance to configure your Service Bus namespace programmatically.
trans-unit.target: You can use a NamespaceMananger instance to configure your Service Bus namespace programmatically.

trans-unit.source: You can use the same connection string to instantiate a client objects (such as QueueClient, TopicClient, and EventHubClient object) that you can use to perform runtime operations such as sending and receiving messages.
trans-unit.target: You can use the same connection string to instantiate a client objects (such as QueueClient, TopicClient, and EventHubClient object) that you can use to perform runtime operations such as sending and receiving messages.

trans-unit.source: To instantiate a client (for example, a Service Bus QueueClient), you can represent the configuration information as a connection string.
trans-unit.target: To instantiate a client (for example, a Service Bus QueueClient), you can represent the configuration information as a connection string.

trans-unit.source: On the client side, there is a CreateFromConnectionString() method that instantiates that client type by using that connection string.
trans-unit.target: On the client side, there is a CreateFromConnectionString() method that instantiates that client type by using that connection string.

trans-unit.source: For example, given the following configuration section
trans-unit.target: For example, given the following configuration section

trans-unit.source: The following code retrieves the connection string, creates a queue, and initializes the connection to the queue.
trans-unit.target: The following code retrieves the connection string, creates a queue, and initializes the connection to the queue.

trans-unit.source: The code in the following section uses the CloudConfigurationManager class.
trans-unit.target: The code in the following section uses the CloudConfigurationManager class.

trans-unit.source: You will now create the worker role that processes the order submissions.
trans-unit.target: You will now create the worker role that processes the order submissions.

trans-unit.source: This example uses the Worker Role with Service Bus Queue Visual Studio project template.
trans-unit.target: This example uses the Worker Role with Service Bus Queue Visual Studio project template.

trans-unit.source: First, use Server Explorer in Visual Studio to obtain the required credentials.
trans-unit.target: First, use Server Explorer in Visual Studio to obtain the required credentials.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have connected Visual Studio to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have connected Visual Studio to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in Solution Explorer right-click the Roles folder under the MultiTierApp project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in Solution Explorer right-click the Roles folder under the MultiTierApp project.

trans-unit.source: Click Add, and then click New Worker Role Project.
trans-unit.target: Click Add, and then click New Worker Role Project.

trans-unit.source: The Add New Role Project dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Add New Role Project dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Role Project dialog box, click Worker Role with Service Bus Queue.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Role Project dialog box, click Worker Role with Service Bus Queue.

trans-unit.source: In the Name box, name the project OrderProcessingRole.
trans-unit.target: In the Name box, name the project OrderProcessingRole.

trans-unit.source: Then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Then click Add.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, right-click the name of your service namespace, then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, right-click the name of your service namespace, then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Properties pane, the first entry contains a connection string that is populated with the namespace endpoint containing the required authorization credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Properties pane, the first entry contains a connection string that is populated with the namespace endpoint containing the required authorization credentials.

trans-unit.source: For example, see the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: For example, see the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: Double-click ConnectionString, and then press Ctrl+C to copy this string to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Double-click ConnectionString, and then press Ctrl+C to copy this string to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole you created in step 5 (make sure that you right-click OrderProcessingRole under Roles, and not the class).
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole you created in step 5 (make sure that you right-click OrderProcessingRole under Roles, and not the class).

trans-unit.source: Then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: On the Settings tab of the Properties dialog box, click inside the Value box for Microsoft.ServiceBus.ConnectionString, and then paste the endpoint value you copied in step 6.
trans-unit.target: On the Settings tab of the Properties dialog box, click inside the Value box for Microsoft.ServiceBus.ConnectionString, and then paste the endpoint value you copied in step 6.

trans-unit.source: Create an OnlineOrder class to represent the orders as you process them from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Create an OnlineOrder class to represent the orders as you process them from the queue.

trans-unit.source: You can reuse a class you have already created.
trans-unit.target: You can reuse a class you have already created.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole project (right-click the project, not the role).
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole project (right-click the project, not the role).

trans-unit.source: Click Add, then click Existing Item.
trans-unit.target: Click Add, then click Existing Item.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the subfolder for FrontendWebRole\Models, and then double-click OnlineOrder.cs to add it to this project.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the subfolder for FrontendWebRole\Models, and then double-click OnlineOrder.cs to add it to this project.

trans-unit.source: In WorkerRole.cs, replace the value of the QueueName variable in WorkerRole.cs from "ProcessingQueue" to "OrdersQueue" as shown in the following code.
trans-unit.target: In WorkerRole.cs, replace the value of the QueueName variable in WorkerRole.cs from "ProcessingQueue" to "OrdersQueue" as shown in the following code.

trans-unit.source: Add the following using statement at the top of the WorkerRole.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following using statement at the top of the WorkerRole.cs file.

trans-unit.source: In the Run() function, inside the OnMessage call, add the following code inside the try clause.
trans-unit.target: In the Run() function, inside the OnMessage call, add the following code inside the try clause.

trans-unit.source: You have completed the application.
trans-unit.target: You have completed the application.

trans-unit.source: You can test the full application by right-clicking the MultiTierApp project in Solution Explorer, selecting Set as Startup Project, and then pressing F5.
trans-unit.target: You can test the full application by right-clicking the MultiTierApp project in Solution Explorer, selecting Set as Startup Project, and then pressing F5.

trans-unit.source: Note that the message count does not increment, because the worker role processes items from the queue and marks them as complete.
trans-unit.target: Note that the message count does not increment, because the worker role processes items from the queue and marks them as complete.

trans-unit.source: You can see the trace output of your worker role by viewing the Azure Compute Emulator UI.
trans-unit.target: You can see the trace output of your worker role by viewing the Azure Compute Emulator UI.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by right-clicking the emulator icon in the notification area of your taskbar and selecting Show Compute Emulator UI.
trans-unit.target: You can do this by right-clicking the emulator icon in the notification area of your taskbar and selecting Show Compute Emulator UI.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Service Bus, see the following resources:
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Service Bus, see the following resources:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Service Bus[sbmsdn]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Service Bus[sbmsdn]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Service Bus service page[sbwacom]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Service Bus service page[sbwacom]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>How to Use Service Bus Queues[sbwacomqhowto]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to Use Service Bus Queues[sbwacomqhowto]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: To learn more about multi-tier scenarios, or to learn how to deploy an application to a cloud service, see:
trans-unit.target: To learn more about multi-tier scenarios, or to learn how to deploy an application to a cloud service, see:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>.NET Multi-Tier Application Using Storage Tables, Queues, and Blobs[mutitierstorage]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>.NET Multi-Tier Application Using Storage Tables, Queues, and Blobs[mutitierstorage]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: You might want to implement the front-end of a multi-tier application in an Azure website instead of an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You might want to implement the front-end of a multi-tier application in an Azure website instead of an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To implement the application you create in this tutorial as a standard web project instead of as a cloud service web role, follow the steps in this tutorial with the following differences:
trans-unit.target: To implement the application you create in this tutorial as a standard web project instead of as a cloud service web role, follow the steps in this tutorial with the following differences:

trans-unit.source: When you create the project, choose the ASP.NET MVC Web Application project template in the Web category instead of the Cloud Service template in the Cloud category.
trans-unit.target: When you create the project, choose the ASP.NET MVC Web Application project template in the Web category instead of the Cloud Service template in the Cloud category.

trans-unit.source: Then follow the same directions for creating the MVC application, until you get to the Cloud configuration manager section.
trans-unit.target: Then follow the same directions for creating the MVC application, until you get to the Cloud configuration manager section.

trans-unit.source: When you create the worker role, create it in a new, separate solution, similar to the original instructions for the web role.
trans-unit.target: When you create the worker role, create it in a new, separate solution, similar to the original instructions for the web role.

trans-unit.source: Now however, you're creating just the worker role in the cloud service project.
trans-unit.target: Now however, you're creating just the worker role in the cloud service project.

trans-unit.source: Then follow the same directions for creating the worker role.
trans-unit.target: Then follow the same directions for creating the worker role.

trans-unit.source: You can test the front-end and back-end separately, or you can run both simultaneously in separate Visual Studio instances.
trans-unit.target: You can test the front-end and back-end separately, or you can run both simultaneously in separate Visual Studio instances.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to deploy the front end to an Azure website, see <linkText>Deploying an ASP.NET Web Application to an Azure Website</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to deploy the front end to an Azure website, see <linkText>Deploying an ASP.NET Web Application to an Azure Website</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to deploy the back end to an Azure cloud service, see <linkText>.NET Multi-Tier Application Using Storage Tables, Queues, and Blobs[mutitierstorage]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to deploy the back end to an Azure cloud service, see <linkText>.NET Multi-Tier Application Using Storage Tables, Queues, and Blobs[mutitierstorage]</linkText><title></title>.
